posts.title: PORSCHEvolution
posts.body: Turn up the volume to enjoy full experience

posts.title: Ferdinand Porsche
posts.body: The history of Porsche goes back to 1875 - the birth year of Ferdinand Porsche. It is he who laid the foundations for a unique company with strong ideals.

posts.title: 1930s
posts.body: Type 64 Racing Coupé: Built for long-distance ‘Berlin–Rom-Wagen’ endurancecompetition. Considered the forefathers of all later Porsche sports cars.

posts.title: 1940s
posts.body: 356 Speedster: Porsche's first production automobile started in Gmündin Austria, where only 49 of these aluminum Porsches were built.

posts.title: 1950s
posts.body: 356 Carrera Cabriolet: Shortly before Porsche celebrated 10th anniversaryof 356 model, 356 had developed into one of the world’s most respected sports cars.

posts.title: 1960s
posts.body: 901: Successor of Porsche 356. Between 14 September and 16 November 1964,82 cars were built. Due to Peugeot was renamed to 911.

posts.title: 1970s
posts.body: 911 Turbo: At the Paris Auto Show Porsche presents the 911 Turbo – the world’s first  production sports car with exhaust turbocharger and pressure regulator.

posts.title: 1980s
posts.body: 911 Carrera Speedster: In 1984 the 911 celebrated it's 20th birthday. It had a lower and flatter windscreen and a simpler manual top that folded beneath a fiberglass cover.

posts.title: 1990s
posts.body: 911: It’s got classic lines, albeit updated with plastic bumpers, with modern technology such as 4x4 ABS and electronic heating.

posts.title: 2000s
posts.body: 911: The sixth generation of the 911 series' the new 911 Turbo with 480PS six-speed manual transmission requires 3.9 seconds from 0 to 100 km/h.

posts.title: 2010s
posts.body: 911 Carrera 4S Coupe: The iconic Porsche 911 sports car celebrates its 50th birthday in 2013. Today's 911 still has many stories to tell. Of heroic race victories, iconic deisgn, childhood dreams. And of a timeless idea.
